Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 ACM International Conference on Underwater Networks (WUWNet)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our oceans are integral to climate regulation, nutrient production, oil and gas retrieval, and transportation. As such, there is significant interest to develop underwater sensor network technologies for scientific, environmental, commercial, safety, and military missions in the oceans. The WUWNet conference has established itself as one of the premier technical venues in the field of underwater sensor networks. The fourteenth ACM WUWNet, which will be held in Atlanta, Oct 23-25, 2019, promises to build on its previous success and further expand the scope. The organizing committee is in charge of putting together a very strong program, including technical sessions, panels, keynote speeches, and special sessions, as well as poster/demo sessions and vendors exhibit.
This main goal of the project is to promote student participation in WUWNet19. Participation in high-quality scientific meetings, such as WUWNet, is an extremely important part of the research training experiences. It allows the students to interact with their peers, gives opportunities the young investigators to learn from senior researchers and scholars, exposes the students to cutting-edge research, and allows the students to take part in discussions that are likely to shape the future of the field. The requested funding will be used to provide travel support for both undergraduate and graduate students who might otherwise be unable to attend the conference.

A total amount of $16,000 will be used to support approximately sixteen students to attend WUWNet19. Special attention will be paid to recruit the first-time attendees from undergraduate and beginning graduate groups. The project will give high preference to support the under-represented groups to participate in WUWNet'19, including women, minorities, and students with disabilities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project is to promote student participation in WUWNet'19. With this goal, the project's major activities include
1) NSF student travel support was advertised among WUWNet participants. Institutions that participated in the past WUWNet conferences were individually contacted. A webpage was created at the wuwnet?19 site: https://wuwnet.acm.org/2019/StudentTravelGrant.htm. The NSF support was acknowledged at the conference website and publication.

2) Thirteen (13) students were awarded the NSF student travel support. We followed the NSF guidelines to grant travel support to two categories of applicants: first-time attendees and under-represented groups.

3) The participation activities of these travel fund awardees were recorded. Feedback from the awardees was collected.

4) Travel reimbursements were processed shortly after the conference for each of the awardees.

Per guidelines from NSF, the following rules were followed to use the NSF student support award:
1. The 1/4-th (25%) of the award will be reserved for first-time attendees who do not have an accepted paper.  Undergraduates and beginning graduate students are strongly encouraged to apply.

2. The 1/4-th (25%) of the award will be reserved for under-represented groups (women, minorities and people with disabilities), who do not need to have an accepted paper.

3. If there is an insufficient number of applicants in the above two categories, funds will not be shifted to others. The award committee will try their best to conduct outreach (e.g. to women and other minority groups) to attract potential attendees.

4. No more than one awardee per institution.

Three students (including one female student) were in the category of the first-time attendees. Two students, female, were allocated to the second category of the under-represented groups. The rest eight students were the regular group.

Three first-time attendees without papers were awarded the NSF travel support. Three female students, one of which was also a first-time awardee without papers, were awarded the NSF travel support. There were eight regular awardees, neither first-time attendees nor under-represented groups. A total of three students were funded.

Nearly all the awardees stayed all three-days at the conferences. Only one student stayed one day because of other obligations. A majority of the awardees presented poster and presentation sessions. They participated in technical discussions. Some of them also served as volunteers. Two notable examples are listed below.  

The awardee from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Navid Barani, won the best poster award for his poster, ?A phase modulation scheme for ultra-low frequency handheld antennas enabling reliable wireless underwater communication.?

The awardee from Rutgers University, Mehdi Rahmati, served as Poster/Demo Chair.
